entry.title: Female with kids at work.. are they the underdog?
entry.content:
Published on: 2025-12-09T23:43:27+0800




I work in a male-dominated job in the finance industry in Germany. The more senior I get, the more I understand why so many women in Germany postpone having children or give up on it entirely. Iâ€™m in my late twenties, I really love my job, but now that the biological clock is ticking, I see the cracks everywhere.

My household income is 175,000 euros alongside my husband (who earns significantly less than me). Thanks to the government, weâ€™re suddenly no longer entitled to reasonable parental benefits. In 2025, with inflation and rising cost of living, that is not a luxury income for two full-time workers. What are we supposed to do? Strategically lower our income before getting pregnant just to receive any support at all?



Iâ€™m tied to my desk from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m, hardly ever working from home, I spent years doing ten unpaid internships to get where I am. Despite this, I still feel a need to achieve more by the time Iâ€™m 30 than any male colleague because I know that, when I have a child, promotions and salary increases donâ€™t just continue the way they used to.

Companies need to stop pretending that maternity protection and parental leave have no effect on a career. At the first instance of â€œMy child is sick, I need to step away for a moment,â€ priorities get questioned. I see it every day with female colleagues. I want to go back to work after giving birth, and I want to look after my child. Why does it have to be a choice? If companies really cared, theyâ€™d build a daycare in the office and offer real flexibility.

As for Karin Prien and the government. You want higher birth rates? Then support the women who financially sustain this country. Icanafford to have a child without support, but when I compare the costs next to my full-time job with the option of reducing my hours and receiving more state benefitsâ€¦ suddenly the math doesnâ€™t add up. And thatâ€™s exactly why so many women postpone it, or decide against it.

The system is broken, and we women are the ones paying the price for it.
